answers.title: Best way to parseDouble with comma as decimal separator?
answers.body:
You can use this (the French locale has , for decimal separator)

NumberFormat nf = NumberFormat.getInstance(Locale.FRANCE);
nf.parse(p);

Or you can use java.text.DecimalFormat and set the appropriate symbols:

DecimalFormat df = new DecimalFormat();
DecimalFormatSymbols symbols = new DecimalFormatSymbols();
symbols.setDecimalSeparator(',');
symbols.setGroupingSeparator(' ');
df.setDecimalFormatSymbols(symbols);
df.parse(p);

comments.body_markdown: This only works if the current default locale happens to use a comma as a decimal separator.
comments.body: This only works if the current default locale happens to use a comma as a decimal separator.

comments.body_markdown: To further mess things up, some locales use comma as a *thousands separator*, in which case "1,234" would parse to 1234.0 instead of throwing an error.
comments.body: To further mess things up, some locales use comma as a thousands separator, in which case "1,234" would parse to 1234.0 instead of throwing an error.

comments.body_markdown: Some European locales such as FRANCE, GERMANY and ITALY use comma as a decimal separator, so you could explicitly use them, rather than relying on the default.
comments.body: Some European locales such as FRANCE, GERMANY and ITALY use comma as a decimal separator, so you could explicitly use them, rather than relying on the default.

comments.body_markdown: The problem with NumberFormat is that it will silently ignore invalid characters. So if you try to parse "1,23abc" it will happily return 1.23 without indicating to you that the passed-in String contained non-parsable characters. In some situations that might actually be desirable, but I don't think it's usually the desired behavior.
comments.body: The problem with NumberFormat is that it will silently ignore invalid characters. So if you try to parse "1,23abc" it will happily return 1.23 without indicating to you that the passed-in String contained non-parsable characters. In some situations that might actually be desirable, but I don't think it's usually the desired behavior.

answers.title: Best way to parseDouble with comma as decimal separator?
answers.body:
As E-Riz points out, NumberFormat.parse(String) parse "1,23abc" as 1.23. To take the entire input we can use:

public double parseDecimal(String input) throws ParseException{
  NumberFormat numberFormat = NumberFormat.getNumberInstance(Locale.getDefault());
  ParsePosition parsePosition = new ParsePosition(0);
  Number number = numberFormat.parse(input, parsePosition);

  if(parsePosition.getIndex() != input.length()){
    throw new ParseException("Invalid input", parsePosition.getIndex());
  }

  return number.doubleValue();
}

comments.body_markdown:
What if the default Locale is something like German, where a comma denotes a decimal place?

You could pass in, for example "1,000,000" which wouldn't parse into German Locale and would then be replaced by "1.000.000" which is not a valid Double.

answers.title: Best way to parseDouble with comma as decimal separator?
answers.body:
This is the static method I use in my own code:

public static double sGetDecimalStringAnyLocaleAsDouble (String value) {

    if (value == null) {
        Log.e("CORE", "Null value!");
        return 0.0;
    }

    Locale theLocale = Locale.getDefault();
    NumberFormat numberFormat = DecimalFormat.getInstance(theLocale);
    Number theNumber;
    try {
        theNumber = numberFormat.parse(value);
        return theNumber.doubleValue();
    } catch (ParseException e) {
        // The string value might be either 99.99 or 99,99, depending on Locale.
        // We can deal with this safely, by forcing to be a point for the decimal separator, and then using Double.valueOf ...
        //http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4323599/best-way-to-parsedouble-with-comma-as-decimal-separator
        String valueWithDot = value.replaceAll(",",".");

        try {
          return Double.valueOf(valueWithDot);
        } catch (NumberFormatException e2)  {
            // This happens if we're trying (say) to parse a string that isn't a number, as though it were a number!
            // If this happens, it should only be due to application logic problems.
            // In this case, the safest thing to do is return 0, having first fired-off a log warning.
            Log.w("CORE", "Warning: Value is not a number" + value);
            return 0.0;
        }
    }
}

answers.title: Best way to parseDouble with comma as decimal separator?
answers.body:
If you don't know the correct Locale and the string can have a thousand separator this could be a last resort:

    doubleStrIn = doubleStrIn.replaceAll("[^\\d,\\.]++", "");
    if (doubleStrIn.matches(".+\\.\\d+,\\d+$"))
        return Double.parseDouble(doubleStrIn.replaceAll("\\.", "").replaceAll(",", "."));
    if (doubleStrIn.matches(".+,\\d+\\.\\d+$"))
        return Double.parseDouble(doubleStrIn.replaceAll(",", ""));
    return Double.parseDouble(doubleStrIn.replaceAll(",", "."));

Be aware: this will happily parse strings like "R 1 52.43,2" to "15243.2".

answers.body_markdown:
Double.parseDouble(p.replace(',','.'))
...is very quick as it searches the underlying character array on a char-by-char basis. The string replace versions compile a RegEx to evaluate.

Basically replace(char,char) is about 10 times quicker and since you'll be doing these kind of things in low-level code it makes sense to think about this. The Hot Spot optimiser will not figure it out... Certainly doesn't on my system.

answers.title: Best way to parseDouble with comma as decimal separator?
answers.body:
In the case where you don't know the locale of the string value received and it is not necessarily the same locale as the current default locale you can use this : 

private static double parseDouble(String price){
    String parsedStringDouble;
    if (price.contains(",") && price.contains(".")){
        int indexOfComma = price.indexOf(",");
        int indexOfDot = price.indexOf(".");
        String beforeDigitSeparator;
        String afterDigitSeparator;
        if (indexOfComma < indexOfDot){
            String[] splittedNumber = price.split("\\.");
            beforeDigitSeparator = splittedNumber[0];
            afterDigitSeparator = splittedNumber[1];
        }
        else {
            String[] splittedNumber = price.split(",");
            beforeDigitSeparator = splittedNumber[0];
            afterDigitSeparator = splittedNumber[1];
        }
        beforeDigitSeparator = beforeDigitSeparator.replace(",", "").replace(".", "");
        parsedStringDouble = beforeDigitSeparator+"."+afterDigitSeparator;
    }
    else {
        parsedStringDouble = price.replace(",", "");
    }

    return Double.parseDouble(parsedStringDouble);

}

It will return a double no matter what the locale of the string is. And no matter how many commas or points there are. So passing 1,000,000.54 will work so will 1.000.000,54 so you don't have to rely on the default locale for parsing the string anymore. The code isn't as optimized as it can be so any suggestions are welcome. I tried to test most of the cases to make sure it solves the problem but I am not sure it covers all. If you find a breaking value let me know.

answers.title: Best way to parseDouble with comma as decimal separator?
answers.body:
In Kotlin you can use extensions as below:

fun String.toDoubleEx() : Double {
   val decimalSymbol = DecimalFormatSymbols.getInstance().decimalSeparator
  return if (decimalSymbol == ',') {
      this.replace(decimalSymbol, '.').toDouble()
  } else {
      this.toDouble()
  }
}

and you can use it everywhere in your code like this:

val myNumber1 = "5,2"
val myNumber2 = "6.7"

val myNum1 = myNumber1.toDoubleEx()
val myNum2 = myNumber2.toDoubleEx()

It is easy and universal!

answers.title: Google Maps Android API v2 and Eclipse, unable to run
answers.body:
Under Application Element in manifest add this for Eclipse :

<meta-data android:name="com.google.android.gms.version" 
 android:value="@integer/google_play_services_version" />

<meta-data android:name="com.google.android.maps.v2.API_KEY"
          android:value="Your KEY" />

If you are using Android Studio with gradle0.7+ then add this line:

<meta-data
        android:name="com.google.android.maps.v2.API_KEY"
        android:value="Your Key" />

items.body_markdown:
I'm having an issue with OpenTelemetry in Java. 

I am in the process of transitioning from Opentracing to OpenTelemetry on a library that is using vert.x. I have included *vertx-opentelemetry* library, which includes *VertxContextStorageProvider* class.

This class is then set as the default context storage.

My issue is that this relies on vert.x being initialized, and breaks my tests which are testing certain parts that just don't need to initialize vert.x to be tested. 

I saw that I can set a system property to enforce OpenTelemetry to load the default context provider. But, honestly, that seems like an overkill if I need to do it in all of my test classes.


Is there any way I can use the default (ThreadLocalContextStorage) implementation? 


I tried creating my own implementation of context provider, but the ClassLoader didn't load it, and still loaded only the vert.x implementation.
items.title: Configuring OpenTelemetry ContextStorage in Java
items.body:
I'm having an issue with OpenTelemetry in Java.

I am in the process of transitioning from Opentracing to OpenTelemetry on a library that is using vert.x. I have included vertx-opentelemetry library, which includes VertxContextStorageProvider class.

This class is then set as the default context storage.

My issue is that this relies on vert.x being initialized, and breaks my tests which are testing certain parts that just don't need to initialize vert.x to be tested.

I saw that I can set a system property to enforce OpenTelemetry to load the default context provider. But, honestly, that seems like an overkill if I need to do it in all of my test classes.

Is there any way I can use the default (ThreadLocalContextStorage) implementation?

I tried creating my own implementation of context provider, but the ClassLoader didn't load it, and still loaded only the vert.x implementation.

comments.body_markdown: Can there be more than one object in each list with the same value? If not, the fastest is to create a `Map` of value to object using one of the lists, then iterate the other list and lookup to find a match. If duplicate values can be present, then you first need to decide what should happen in that case, e.g. if first list has 2 objects with value "foo", and second list has 3 objects with value "foo", what should happen?

answers.title: What is the best way to search 2 lists to compare values?
answers.body:
Assuming values in list2 are unique, build a Map keyed by values from list2, then iterate list1 to find matches:

Map<String, Class2> map2 = new HashMap<>();
for (Class2 obj2 : list2)
    if (map2.put(obj2.getValue(), obj) != null)
        throw new IllegalStateException("Duplicate value in list2: " + obj2.getValue());
for (Class1 obj1 : list1) {
    Class2 obj2 = map2.get(obj1.getValue());
    if (obj2 != null) {
        // found match
    }
}

What is the best way to search the lists to compare the elements in the list to find which elements from the two lists have a link?

The simplest way is to use 2 loops but what is a more efficient way?

comments.body_markdown: Don't you miss a `return` inside the flatMap?
comments.body: Don't you miss a return inside the flatMap?

comments.body_markdown: You need a return statement in the flatMap if you are to use bracers. Another thing to point out, `.doOnNext` is used for side effects, its a fire-and-forget operator, which means you will probably get a race condition with validate getting executed and then it will save even if validation fails .doOnNext should be used for things when you dont care about the result. Like logging etc.

Like logging etc.

comments.body_markdown: flatMap won't be executed if the upstream flux/mono is *empty*. An empty publisher *shorts* any downstream operations. To protect yourself against such cases, you can use *switchIfEmpty* operator. For example, you can use it to raise an error instead of shorting downstream operations. Example: `getPlayerOrdersForAuction(...).switchIfEmpty(Mono.error(() -> new IllegalArgumentException("No order found for input player in auction")).map...`

To protect yourself against such cases, you can use switchIfEmpty operator. For example, you can use it to raise an error instead of shorting downstream operations. Example: getPlayerOrdersForAuction(...).switchIfEmpty(Mono.error(() -> new IllegalArgumentException("No order found for input player in auction")).map...

items.title: Spring webflux: code breaking the reactive chain, which causes it not to be executed
items.body:
I am currently experimenting with reactive programming and Spring Webflux. I am facing a situation where part of my code is not being executed. After doing some research I understood that when such situation arises it might mean that my code is breaking the "reactive chain".

Here is the code causing me headaches:

return getPlayerOrdersForAuction(order.getPlayerAddress(), order.getAuctionID())
        .map(el -> el.getWeight())
        .reduce((long) 0,(a,b) -> a+b)
        .doOnNext(sum -> validateOrder(order,sum)) // side effect
        .flatMap(el -> {
           return orderRepository.save(order); 
        });

Everything gets executed besides the save() operation in the flatMap(). In this case how am I breaking the reactive chain? What concept am I misunderstanding/missing? Since save() returns a Mono shouldn't it be captured in the main reactive flow by flatMap() and thus preserve the chain?

NB: please don't mind the horrible code structure, this is just experimentation.

```gradle
implementation group: 'com.google.inject', name: 'guice', version: '5.1.0'
```

```java
import com.google.inject.Singleton;
```

it reports:

**I use IntellijIDEA.**  
I don't know much about it, so I would appreciate it if someone could explain to me what I'm doing wrong or how to correctly add this library to the project.
